title: Impressive for a mobile Microsoft app!
text:
I am a student and I use teams a lot, including for notebook entries, but there was a problem. I couldn‚Äôt get photos and videos to my computer fast and into teams. THIS APP MAKES IT SO EASY! just go to your desired import folder for photos and videos, and tap the plus, then allow access to all photos and BOOM you can get anything from your phone‚Äôs photo library and add it in and when you go back on the computer, there the pictures are! But don‚Äôt go away if you don‚Äôt need pictures, there‚Äôs more! You can get this app and see your team‚Äôs notifications on the go and even submit assignments like normal. If you don‚Äôt have a sort of Microsoft Account though, now you can leave.

Thanks for reading.

It takes away from the productivity of my day to have multiple groups showing up when I‚Äôve already hidden and muted them. Ola‚Äôs fix this ASAP

title: Great capabilities, but needs UI improvements
text:
Shifting to Teams for collaboration is an overall effective strategy, however the UI in teams needs to be improved to make collaborating and managing information fluid.  With more complex organizations where generally the information handled is both sensitive and ‚Äòneed to know‚Äô, the sheer amount of teams, channels, and chat groups to compartmentize information can become overwhelming.  Tack in business portals, support groups,  apps and workflows and the complexity grows.  
The UI need a better way to organize and present these.   The UI also needs to present what‚Äôs changing, being posted, and being mentioned better than a dot on an icon, or an activity stream, both of which are dated approaches.
It also needs to suggest best approach when sharing information to reuse existing teams, channels,  sites, chat groups, etc. and to help reduce the sheer number on new things from growing.

title: App causes hearing loss
text: Teams does not respond to the iPhone master volume and will output audio at a dangerously high volume level even when the master volume is all the way to zero. My ears are ringing after a teams call on my phone. The iPhone Headphone safety feature is disabled by teams so that is another danger.

title: Communication an Collaboration Super App
text: There‚Äôs not much more one can say about Teams and it‚Äôs worthy competitors, but it has completely replaced the old paradigm of email and shared documents. The fact that you can interact with content directly through Teams and not be required to go to another application is a very welcome addition made possible by the inherency of the integrated and extensible Microsoft ecosystem.

title: Valuable tool for work on the go.
text:
For me, the best use of Teams is on the desktop. But the ability to still work effectively and efficiently on the mobile app speaks to the quality design, workflow, and continued improvement that Microsoft‚Äôs has done to empower the multiplatform experience. 

The design is of high-quality and resembles the desktop experience in just the right ways to enable a seamless switch and ease of use between the two platforms. But meaningful consideration was given to the mobile app to make it usable in ways that are most intuitive for, in my case, the iPhone.

title: Pretty good, room for improvement
text:
Rating: 4 out of 5 stars for Microsoft Teams

Microsoft Teams is an incredible application for facilitating communication and collaboration, making it one of the most robust options on the market. It excels in several aspects:

1. Seamless Communication: Microsoft Teams offers an array of communication tools, including chat, video calls, and document sharing, which enhances team collaboration and keeps everyone connected.

2. Integration with Microsoft 365: The tight integration with Microsoft 365 allows for efficient document management and sharing, making it easy to collaborate on projects and access files within the platform.

3. User-Friendly Interface: The user interface is intuitive and user-friendly, making it accessible for users with varying levels of tech proficiency.

4. Versatile Features: Teams provides a variety of features, from channels and notifications to third-party app integrations, making it adaptable to different business needs.

However, there are a couple of downsides to consider:

1. Buggy Performance: Over extended periods of use, Microsoft Teams can become buggy and require occasional restarting, which can disrupt workflow and cause frustration.

2. Overlap with SharePoint: The integration between Teams and SharePoint can sometimes be confusing and lead to duplication of files and content, which may require some additional management.

Overall, Microsoft Teams is a powerful tool for communication and collaboration, but it could benefit from addressing the performance issues and improving the integration with SharePoint to fully streamline the user experience.

title: Fantastic!
text: The app has really taken collaboration to a new level, in my opinion. The hand-off between desktop and mobile is seamless and the experiences, almost identical.
